Help.Description:
The #chat command is used to create peer to peer connections to other mud clients, typically for the purpose of chatting and sending files.
This is a decentralized chat system, meaning you have to exchange ip addresses and port numbers with other users in order to connect to them.
Help.Example:
Launches a private chat server. The port number is optional. (default 4050)
People can connect to your chat server instance by specifying your ip address and port number.

By default, your name is set to TinTin. However, most servers will reject you if there is already someone with that name already connected. That chat name can include color codes. Some names aren't accepted by tt++ chat servers, like the name 'all', and names longer than 20 characters.
Is used to connect to another chat server. The port number is optional. (default 4050)

The default chat color is bold red\. This can be changed with the '#chat color' command.
Example: #chat color bold yellow Example using a 256 color code: #chat color <cde>
This is the main command used for communication. If you use '#chat message all', the message is marked as public and send to everyone you are connected to.
This command works exactly like #chat message, except in appearance as all it does is prepend your name to the message.
This command allows pasting, appending input that is followed in quick succession to the message. Keep in mind that most mud clients won't properly receive messages that are longer than 40 lines.
Replies to the last person you received a private message from.
Sends a raw data string to another person and subsequently requires knowledge of the Mud Master Chat Protocol (MMCP) in order to use it.
DND stands for 'do not disturb' and toggles your DND state. When enabled, all new incoming connections are automatically closed.

Sets your ip address, which isn't set by default, and is sent when connecting to another mud client. TinTin# ignores the reported ip of other MUD clients and grabs the socket address. Other MUD clients might need it set.

Shows all people you are connected to. The first column shows a reference number for the connection, which can be used instead of the connection's name when sending someone a message. The second column shows the connection's name. The third column shows flags set for the connection, (P)rivate, (I)gnore, (S)erve, (F)orward to user, and (f)orward from user. The following columns show ip, port, and MUD client name.
Shows your name, ip address, port, download dir, reply, and DND status.
Ignores the specified user, who won't be notified that you're ignoring them.
Disables the peek and request command for the given connection.
Is the opposite of the private command. Allows the peek and request command to work for a given connection. New connections are public by default.
Shows the given user's public connections.
Obtains the specified user's public connections and automatically connect to them, if not already.
Displays the ping request time round-trip, in milli seconds.
Closes the connection to the specified user or all users.
Forwards all chat messages to the specified user as snoop data. To avoid infinite loops, forwarding to a user is disabled when receiving snoop data from that user.
Forwards everything that is saved in the scrollback buffer to the specified user as snoop data.

Forwards all public chat messages to the specified user plus all public chat messages from that user to everyone you are connected to. To avoid infinite loops the messages are forwarded as private messages.

Assigns the specified user to a group. You can use a group name with the emote, message, and send commands. If you use '#chat group' without an argument, it will behave like '#chat who', showing a list of all users and their group name.
Sends a file to the given user. They must accept it before transfer begins.
Accepts a file transfer after the user has offered to send a file.
Declines a file transfer after the user has offered to send a file.
Cancels a file transfer after it has been started.
Shows information about a file transfer currently in progress.
Sets the directory path location where new downloads are to be placed.
